feed.title: It All Comes Downton Fun
feed.subtitle: Downton Abbey's cast and creators on why their sudsy, upstairs-downstairs drama became one of TV's biggest hits.

link.Abstract: Downton Abbey's cast and creators on why their sudsy, upstairs-downstairs drama became one of TV's biggest hits.
link.title: [ more ]

link.Abstract: "Mastercheese Theatre." Sudsy period drama Downton Abbey comes to Canada's VisionTV beginning Feb. 22.
link.title: Downton Abbey

link.Abstract: By the time the you're reading this, the annual beginning-of-the-year tradition of news conferences singing the praises of new TV hopefuls such as Smash, Scandal, Bent, GCB, Remodeled and The B— in Apartment 23 will be over.
link.title: Overheard at the TV Critics' Meeting in LA

link.Abstract: Silent film The Artist was came out as the top nominee during the Golden Globes nominations announcement Thursday morning. George Clooney film The Descendants and Emma Stone's The Help were recognized with five nods apiece.
link.title: A Moment of Silence, Please, For the Golden Globes Nominations; The Artist, The Descendants Lead Nods

link.Abstract: Follow Dose.ca on Twitter
link.title: Follow Dose.ca on Twitter

content.div:
Damnably addictive. Mastercheese Theatre. Topsy turvy upstairs-downstairs drama at its jolliest. Guilty pleasure, what? Downton Abbey, said The New Yorker, "goes down so easily that it's (akin to) scarfing handfuls of caramel corn while swigging champagne."

Forget for a moment how utterly appalled the gentility who inhabit the upstairs quarters of Downton Abbey's 100-room manor would be at the mere thought of swigging champagne (it's meant to be sipped, dear boy, not guzzled down like some navvy's filthy brew); Downton Abbey's vivid characters, with their litany of romantic entanglements, have become as familiar as any in popular fiction today.

PBS has dressed Downton Abbey up into its biggest hit in years. And, beginning Feb. 22, Canada's VisionTV will repeat the entire series, starting with the Sept. 26, 2010, premiere episode that introduced an unsuspecting North American public to Robert Crawley, the Earl of Grantham, played by Hugh Bonneville, Lady Mary Crawley, played by Michelle Dockery, and a host of others.

Never mind that last month's season premiere on PBS averaged 4.2 million viewers, double PBS's prime-time average, and 18 per cent higher than Downton Abbey's first season. Never mind that Downton Abbey is now seen by more viewers than those who watch prestige dramas like Mad Men, Boardwalk Empire, Breaking Bad and Emmy contender, Homeland. And never mind that those numbers failed to include those viewers who watched later replays, or recorded the series on a PVR.

What's most intriguing about the way Downton Abbey has captured the public imagination is in the weekly dissection and analysis of episodes, from the Fleet Street tabloids and broadsheets, USA Today, Time magazine, The Washington Post and The Los Angeles Times, as well as online sites as varied as Slate, TV Fanatic, Zap2it, Television Without Pity, Flavorwire, Unreality TV and SouthFloridaGayNews.com, which wrote: "The only thing that could possibly be better than watching Downton Abbey's Maggie Smith, as the Dowager Countess, stop the rest of the cast dead in their tracks with withering glances and haughty comments, would be watching her spar with another matriarch of her calibre." Cue Shirley MacLaine, starting next season, as the visiting mother of Downton Abbey's American-born Cora, Countess of Grantham, played by Elizabeth McGovern.

Downton Abbey owes its creative origins to a chance meeting between Gosford Park screenwriter Julian Fellowes and U.K. film mogul Gareth Neame, Masterpiece Theatre executive producer Rebecca Eaton told TV critics recently in Los Angeles. Neame asked Fellowes if he had ever considered doing anything similar to Gosford Park on television, and the idea for Downton Abbey was born. Downton Abbey made an instant impression in the U.K., with 12 million viewers, and a second season became an inevitability.

Neame admitted he was taken aback. He designed Downton Abbey to last just one season, and to tell a self-contained story. Many of the tale's labyrinthine subplots and open questions are answered by the season's end, which is one reason why he chose to jump ahead several years for the second season, and may do so again next year.

Viewers of the VisionTV version will catch Downton Abbey at its very beginning.

"The original idea was to open with the Titanic, because it felt that was the one moment in history that everyone understands as being a momentous time in 20th-century history," Neame explained. "The outbreak of World War I felt like the next momentous period in world history."

By the time the first season ended, Neame could see the writing on the wall: There would be a second season. That first season ended, then, with Bonneville's Earl of Grantham saying, "We are at war with Germany."

The third season, Neame said, will likely open in the post-War years, leading up to the outbreak of the Second World War.

Downton Abbey's costumes play a large part in the story's narrative, more so than the casual viewer might assume. Dockery admitted the actors suffer from "costume envy" at times.

This elicited a knowing laugh from Neame.

"I know this is an actor's question, but one of the wonderful things about the show is that the costumes are a central part of the drama," Neame said. "Julian Fellowes was our expert on this world. I don't think any of us were particularly expert. The more we kind of found out about it, though, the more we discovered that these aristocrats had no function whatsoever. For the women, particularly, much of their day was spent changing, dressing, undressing, changing into something else. There were four or five or six different outfits worn in any one day. It made it very difficult in editing, sometimes, when we wanted to move scenes around and we found ourselves constantly being constricted. 'Oh, my God, they're dressed for lunch, not for dinner.' 'They're dressed in something else for tea, breakfast.' It became central to the storytelling."

McGovern said that, while the costumes are breathtaking to behold, they're not always practical to wear.

"I always find it fascinating that women in that era would constrict themselves so profoundly, by wearing these very, very tight corsets, and yet still feel free and liberated," McGovern said. "Just today, I found myself tottering around on these incredibly high heels, to impress the journalists. I'm in such pain at the moment, I realize nothing has actually changed at all."

Neame has his own theory as to why Downton Abbey has struck a chord with viewers in the age of American Idol and Two and a Half Men.

"It's chock full of story in every episode," Neame said. "All 20 characters have their own stories in each episode. Some are resolved within the episode; some of them continue. The narrative structure remains.

"It's a quintessentially British genre -- this idea of a country house in a period in history. Many, many such productions have been made over the years, but very, very few of them are original writing. I think it's the combination of Julian Fellowes' writing, a contemporary narrative with original stories, combined with his uncanny ability to keep 20 plates spinning in the air at the same time. It's modern, contemporary storytelling, but in a period setting.

"I think audiences love this sort of social interaction, the way these people lived under a different code from the way we live now. The manners, the rules seem somewhat absurd to us, and yet we're intrigued by them. I would say Downton Abbey is closer to something like Mad Men, where you have a period setting but modern writing, than it is to a lot of former Masterpiece Theatre productions like Pride & Prejudice, where a Victorian novel is adapted to the screen, and the writer, to a greater or lesser degree, has to be faithful to the original material that's been laid down. We have the freedom that any modern narrative would have."

McGovern concurred.

"It's historically accurate, emotionally true, and it's a lot of fun," she said. "That's my answer. It's fun to watch."

link.Abstract: Silent film The Artist was came out as the top nominee during the Golden Globes nominations announcement Thursday morning. George Clooney film The Descendants and Emma Stone's The Help were recognized with five nods apiece.
